speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks whether they should offer a formal excuse for arriving at the party, or just enter without any apology.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says elaborate introductions are out of fashion; they will not perform a masked Cupid act or a memorized prologue. He says they will let others judge them as they wish, but they will dance a measure (a dance) and then leave.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks for a torch because he does not want to dance; feeling heavy-hearted, he will carry the light instead.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio insists that Romeo must dance.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he will not dance; while Mercutio has nimble dancing shoes, his own soul is like lead, pinning him to the ground.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio tells Romeo that, as a lover, he should borrow Cupid’s wings and rise above ordinary limits.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is too deeply wounded by Cupid’s arrow to fly with his light feathers; he is so weighed down that he cannot leap above his sadness and sinks under love’s burden.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio replies that if Romeo sinks under love’s burden, he is burdening love in return, which is too heavy for something so tender.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo questions whether love is tender; he finds it rough, rude, boisterous, and painful like a thorn.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio advises Romeo to fight back if love is rough—prick love back and defeat it. He then asks for a mask to hide his face, saying he does not care if anyone notices his odd looks; let the frowning ladies blush instead.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges everyone to enter and start dancing immediately.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo again asks for a torch; let the carefree ones dance on the rushes (floor covering). He says he will follow an old saying and be a candle-holder, watching others play a game he is finished with.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio uses wordplay: 'dun’s the mouse' means 'keep still,' but if Romeo is stuck (dun) in the mire of love, they will pull him out. He says they are wasting daylight (time) by delaying.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo objects that they are not actually burning daylight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio clarifies that by delaying they waste their torchlight needlessly, like lighting lamps by day. He says his intended meaning is wiser than mere cleverness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees their intention in going to the masque is good, but it is not wise to go.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio asks Romeo why he is reluctant to attend the feast, prompting him to explain his mood.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he had a dream last night, hinting at his troubled state of mind.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio replies that he also dreamed, setting up a playful exchange.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks what Mercutio dreamed, continuing their banter.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio puns that dreamers often lie, meaning both tell falsehoods and recline in bed.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo counters that dreams can be true, but only while asleep in bed.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio launches into his Queen Mab speech, describing the tiny fairy who causes people’s dreams by riding over them as they sleep. He details her miniature chariot and how she makes lovers dream of love, courtiers of etiquette, lawyers of fees, ladies of kisses (sometimes punished with blisters), courtiers of favors, parsons of extra income, and soldiers of battle—before they wake frightened. He adds that Mab tangles horses’ manes and maids’ hair, and teaches maids to bear weight, making them women. This extravagant speech mocks Romeo’s belief in dreams.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo interrupts, telling Mercutio to stop because he is talking nonsense.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio agrees that he talks of dreams, which are the products of a lazy mind, made of empty fantasy—as insubstantial as air and more changeable than the wind, which now flatters the cold north but may turn angrily toward the south.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says this talk of wind is distracting them; supper is over and they will be late for the party.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo fears they are too early, because he dreads that some fateful event beginning tonight will end his despised life by an untimely death. But he resigns himself to whatever power guides his course and urges them onward.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio orders the drum to sound, signaling their departure for the Capulet feast.
